rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of methods for the analysis of bile.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During this investigation, methods for the determination of the principal constituents ot bile have been studied. Since fundamentally, the composition of bile depends upon physiological processes a review is also presented of the main physiological and biochemical factors which affect the chemical composition of bile. A summary of available analytical data will also be presented. Methods for the analysis of these constituents of the bile, viz: bile-pigments, bile acids, and cholesterol have also been investigated. The errors inherent in each method have been noted. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The heat capacity of gelatin gels.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In this work heat capacity measurements have been made upon gelatin gels in order to obtain some information concerning the relationship which exists between the gelatin and the water in a gelatin gel. Heat capacity curves have been obtained for dry gelatin, an 88% gel and a 24% gel, and a calculation has been made of the amount of water in a 24% gel which is in the same state as that in an 88% gel. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Washington Irving et la France.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Washington Irving avait six ans quand la Révolution française éclata. Son père était un des commerçants de New York dont les affaires souffrirent à cause des guerres européennes,et, naturellement, le jeune Washington entendit bien des discussions au sujet de la Révolution. Plusieurs années après, en 1849, quand il fit une visite à la maison natale, il raconta à son neveu Pierre Monroe Irving un incident qui montre la forte impression faite sur son esprit par les histoires de la Révolution quand il était encore un enfant. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.
Irving, Washington, 1783-1859.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The petrology of certain igneous rocks of Newton township, Ontario.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the summer of 1930, the writer was engaged in the detailed mapping of the geology of Newton and other townships, in Ontario, comprising the Algoma Eastern Railway Land Grant, primarily with the object of determining their economic possibilities. In the execution of this work an interesting rock assemblage was encountered on the northern boundary of Newton Township, between Mile Posts I and 11. It was deemed that the petrology and age relationships of these rocks was worthy of a more intensive study, and that such an investigation would form a suitable thesis subject. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Equilibria existing in the three-component system : water, calcium oxide, sulphur dioxide over the temperature range 00 to 250 C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work to be described in this thesis forms a part of a general investigation which is being carried out in this laboratory on sulphite systems. This series of researches was instituted for two reasons, In the first place, there was very little available data on solutions of sulphurous acid and its salts, and much of what was available was of such a nature as to be open to question. Such experiments as had been carried out were usually confined to a narrow concentration or temperature range. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in hydrogen migration.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The question of the migration of atoms and radicals is one of the most important problems in organic chemistry. This phenomenon is found associated with two specific types of atom migration, namely that involved in (a) intermolecular and that in (b) intramolecular reactions. Of the various atoms and radicals which play a marked role in migration. the hydrogen atom on the one hand, and the acyl radicals on the other, represent two of the most important types. At the same time the less well-known phenomena associated with the migration of oxygen and chlorine atoms offer much of theoretical interest. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The planned economy in the capitalist state.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Read the City articles in the great newspapers", says Bernard Shaw, "and you will ask yourselves if you are not living in a lunatic asylum. The answer is that you are." Mr. Shaw's shafts may be sharp, but they always are well-aimed. One pities indeed the layman's perplexity as he tries in vain to understand what is going on around him. Breadlines coiled "like drugged serpents" around the feet of skyscrapers, while brass-throated oracles incantate their magic formulas overproduction, underconsumption, oversaving, underspending. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Canadian tariff : a political instrument and an economic expedient, or, Post-war Canadian tariff, policies and practice.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The writer of this monograph makes no pretense to the presentation of an exhaustive treatise. The Customs Tariff has remained long enough the pet topic of Economic Debating Societies and professional politicians. An extensive and prolonged study of Canadian statues concerning the tariff, customs administration, bounties and external preferences has convinced the writer that, in the words of the Australian Tariff Enquiry Committee, "The tariff is a dangerous drug in the hands of those who are not properly qualified to handle it". [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology of the district about Lake Aylmer, Eastern Townships, Province of Quebec; (a report on a detailed investigation of typical part of this section of the Appalachian region).
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The history of mineral development in the Eastern Townships of Quebec has been long and varied, with a continuous output of a variety of products for many years. Several geologicalreports on the area have been published, but with one or two exceptions, these have either dealt with the general geology of large sections of the country, with little reference to the mineral possibilities, or, in the case of economic reports, they have been devoted solely to one group of deposits as, for example, asbestos or copper (1). The object of the present work is to give as complete a geological history as possible for the small area examined, and to study in detail its economic possibilities. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The nature and origin of the glacial and post-glacial deposits lying between the city of Montreal, and the Canadian shield.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The superficial deposits of Pleistocene and post-Pleistocene age in the vicinity of Montreal, possess many interesting features, the origin of which is obscure in many cases and difficult to explain. The object of this present thesis is to describe the forms of these deposits and the materials composing them, and to explain their origin. Only the broader problems are dealt with and there yet remains a vast amount of work to be done before a true and complete picture can be made of the events that have taken place in this area since Pleistocene time. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The means and modes of living on the pioneer fringe of land settlement : with special reference to the Peace River area.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study is the result of three years of research on the pioneer area of Western Canada under the direction of the Canadian Pioneer ProblemsCommittee. This Committee was formed in 1928 as a result of deliberations of the American Geographical Society who established the Committee at that time for the purpose of studying the various economic and sociological aspects of the problems of settlement. Haphazard land settlement of the past has led to many subsequent problems for the countries in which the frontier has appeared. Too often migration to the fringe has resulted in marginal living for the settlers. Land settlement at the present time is changing due to the growing urban standard of living which the settlers demand. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Frontier and pioneer life -- Peace River Valley (B.C. and Alta.)
Sociology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the physiology of the adrenal cortex.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: either side of the middle line, and immediately above and in front of the anterior pole of the kidney. In mamals the adrenal gland is composed of two parts, the cortex and the medulla. The origins of these two are quite different, and though in mamals they are intimately associated as to anatomical position, in other groups of animals the are more or less separate, being completeq so in Elasmobranch fishes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Large-scale merchandising in Canada: some economic implications.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The importance of wholesale and retail trading in the eoonomic system as a whole is not always sufficiently realized. On the basis of records of the Census of Merchandisingand Service Establishments in Canada of 1930, it has been estimated that the total expenses of retail merchandising establishments amounted to $661,347,OOO, those of retail service establishments to $184,736,000. and those of wholesale establishments to $345,842,000 (1) or a grand total for the distributive trades of $1,172,000,000. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The kinetics of the oxidation of gaseous hydrogen iodide.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Until recently the oxidation of gaseous compounds has been thought to be a predominantly heterogeneous process. It is now known that practically all these reactions proceed by a chain mechanism. A large number of investigations have been made recently on reactions of this sort, (1), (2), and the general conclusions drawn from them are given below. (1) All these redctionsproceed by a chain mechanism, the termination of the chains being either in the gas or at the wall. If the latter is the case packing the reaction bulb will cause a pronounced retardation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Food reserves in trees with special reference to the paper birch Betula alba. var. Papyrifera.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The underlying causes which determine the type of food reserve in any cell of a tree, and which direct its change in form and location, are still comparatively unknown; it isthe object of this thesis to sum up our present knowledge of tree reserves, to add, if possible, to this knowledge by further experiment, and to apply the whole to the importantquestion of winter cold resistance. It is clear that a study of food reserves is of less importance with tropical trees than with trees of temperate climates, since the former, having a faTourable environment (as regards temperature) throughout the year, do not need to store reserves for use during recovery from periods of arrested growth, but only for such functions as flowering and fruiting, which are known to be related to the assimilatory ratio. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Botany.
Trees -- Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The origin and occurrence of the chromite deposits of the Eastern Townships, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The presence of deposits of chromite in the Eastern Townships of Quebec, has been known since 1842 and in the annual reports of the Geological Survey of Canada and of theQuebec Bureau of Mines, as well as in other geological literature published since that time, there are numerous references to new discoveries, and brief descriptions of individual deposits are given. More detailed investigations have been made by Obalski(l) 1894-95, 98, Cirkel(2) 1909, Dresser(3) 1913, Harvie(4), and Denis(5). While these authors have attacked the problem largely from the economic point of view, they have also given consideration to the question of the origin of the deposits, and without exception they have supported the theory of origin by magmatic segregation, which was first advanced by Adams(6) in 1894. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Stark effect in the molecular spectrum of hydrogen.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: So far as atomic spectra are concerned the study of the Stark effect may be said to be well established both theoretically and experimentally in most of its fundamental features. The equivalent ls not true in the ease of molecular spectra, for our knowledge of the effect of an external electric field upon a radiating molecule is at best only very meagre. This state of affairs is due largely to the fact that many atomic spectra exhibit large Stark displacementa in electric fields of the magnitude easily obtained in experiment, whereas most of the attempts to detect similar effects in band spectra have yielded negative results. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The significance of Milton's political theories.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Great men are weavers working with the threads of the world's hopes and ideals. They weave the never ending pattern of history. Occasionally among these men, comes one who gathers up the threads into a striking design that ever after becomes an integral part of the central theme. It is my purpose to show that Milton was one of these men. There exists today a group of historical and political pragmatists who believe that the only law is the law of expediency. We cannot teach either political maxims or moral laws. they say, for we live ina constantly changing social reality which will make the laws of today useless slogans for the future. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An improved semi-micro Kjeldahl method for estimation of organic nitrogen.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Carbonyl compounds are frequently identified by means of their 2, 4-dini trophenylhydrazones. These derivatives are solids in the vast majority of cases and can be compared with those already known by their melting points. To establish the identity of new ones, however, an analysis is necessary. For various reasons the Kjeldahl method for estimating nitrogen is usually used. In applying the method in this laboratory, it was found that low results were frequently obtained on compounds of known structure. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The employment and unemployment problems of the railway industry of Canada with particular reference to the City of Montreal.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The railways have always attracted attention in Canada because of the part they have played in the development of the country. So closely has their development been linked with thatof the nation that the history of the railways has almost been the history of Canada. It was the railways that opened up the West, and it was the railways that brought the Maritime Provinces and British Columbia into Confederation and forged one country out of several scattered settlements. But it is the present, not the past, that counts in the final analysis. It is the position the railway industry holds in the transportation system of the country that is the strongest reason for attaching importance to its activities. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Economic development in French Canada, 1740-1760.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis, which deals with the last decades of the French regime in Canada, is the first part of a further thesis, which I hope to prepare, dealing with economic and social development in Canada from 1740 to 1770, that is, the transition period from French to English rule. The object of the present account is, therefore, to give some description of just what Great Britain received when Canada was ceded to her in 1763. The most outstanding characteristics of economic activity in French Canada were inertness and government paternalism, the former usually being attributed to the latter. An attempt has been made to correct this impression to some degree and to arrive at a balance of the various factors which conditioned the economic life of Canada. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: History.
Canada -- Economic conditions -- To 1763.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A comparison of some European ballads.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis contains some Polish, Slovak, Serbian, and Finnish ballads, collected in America and rendered into English for the first time by the author. There are also some translations of the Finnish ballads from the Kanteletar of Elias Lonnrot. A brief summary of the theories of poetic origins is given, some additional corroborative evidence in behalf of the communal theory of ballad origin included, and a reasonable comprehensive theory suggested. Similarities and differences in form and material among European ballads are analysed. A description of the later history of the ballad concludes the discussion.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ballads -- Europe -- History and criticism.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A comparison of the kinetics of homogeneous and heterogeneous gas reactions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Chemical kinetics is one of the most recent branohes of physical chemistry. It has however, amply justified its existence by throwing light on two of the major problems of chemistry. Suoh problems for example as: the mechanism of reactions and the nature of chemical change, and to some extent the much discussed and investigated question of affinity, the latter prior to the last decade having been studied largely by investigations of systems in their initial and final states, with little or no oonsideration of the path by whichthey reached such states. In addition, much of what we now know concerning the mechanism and use of catalysts, from both the theoretical and practical aspects, is due to investigations carried out in the field of reaction velocities, and to mention only one more instance, our knowledge of the nature of surfaces and their very oonsiderableimportance in promoting chemical reaction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the reaction between unsaturated hydrocarbons and the halogen hydrides.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The object of this study was to carry out experiments which might elucidate the mechanism of reaction between the olefines and halogen hydrides. For this purpose the velocity of reaction between propylene and hydrogen chloride, in the liquid state, was measured over a considerable temperature range. The influence of heterogenous surface and of hydride concentration were determined and the reaction between propylene and hydrogen bromide in various solvents investigated. A review is given below of the previous work in this field. In this connection it will be shown that the investigation has an objective of more far reaching importance than just the elucidation of the mechanism of the particular reaction examined and that the experiments have an essential bearing on the validity of the discontinuity in reaction velocity at the critical temperature, which was discovered in this laboratory. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The English novel of rural life since 1900.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is difficult for us, perhaps, since we live in a period when the literature of rural life is read by a large section of the public, to realise the slow development of what we now term variously the literature of external nature, of the soil, and of the life lived on the land. All varieties of Nature writing are appearing today, from poetry and the light essay to the novel of country life, and the phrase "return to Nature" is on many lips. To study the origin of this literature of rural life is to note the gradual growthof a feeling for natural beauty, and its expression in literature, and in particular, the slow appreciation of the life lived by rural folk on their farms or in secluded hamlets. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Country life in literature.
English fiction -- 20th century -- History and criticism.
English.
